G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, §14, every residential lease in Massachusetts includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3, as the amount in controversy is less than $25,000 and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred in Lowell, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3, as the amount in controversy is less than $25,000 and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred in Lowell, Massachusetts.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.000 et seq..proposition: Landlords are obligated to maintain premises in compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. §410.000 et seq.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.750 and \u00a7410.5.proposition: The presence of mold and unsafe levels of moisture constitute conditions “which may endanger or materially impair the health or safety of occupants,” in violation of 105 C.M.R. §410.750 and §410.550.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises caused by the landlord’s neglect of maintenance or repair obligations constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The court explicitly reaffirms that negligent failure to repair known defects can violate the Massachusetts statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. It cites prior cases where a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which the landlord had notice was held to violate § 14, and clarifies that some degree of landlord fault (at least negligence) tied to conditions interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment is required. This directly supports the proposition that substantial interference caused by a landlord’s neglect of maintenance or repair obligations constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon… Darmetko… Dorgan….”}

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises caused by the landlord’s neglect of maintenance or repair obligations constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment when substantial interference with tenants’ use of the premises is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, regardless of intent. Although Blackett involves noise from a lounge rather than classic repair/maintenance failures, the court explicitly cites prior Massachusetts cases where failure to supply heat, light, power, or to remedy defective conditions breached quiet enjoyment, and it rejects any distinction between landlord nonfeasance and malfeasance in such circumstances. Thus it supports the proposition that substantial interference arising from neglect of maintenance/repair obligations can constitute a violation of the covenant.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services).... Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Failure to maintain safe and sanitary conditions can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely links the landlord’s statutory quiet enjoyment liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 to its failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions, specifically repeated sewage flooding. The opinion explains that § 14 is part of a remedial scheme for landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing and concludes that Gem is liable for interfering with quiet enjoyment because it violated its duty to maintain sanitary conditions, allowing repeated flooding that impaired the tenant’s use of the apartment. This directly supports the proposition that failure to maintain safe and sanitary conditions can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… The objectives of these statutes go beyond deterrence of intentional wrongdoing; unsanitary conditions in an apartment cause harm to the occupants whether the landlord has acted intentionally, negligently, or innocently… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Davis v. Comerford, 483 Mass. 164 (2019).proposition: Failure to maintain safe and sanitary conditions can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions—including failing to repair the ventilation and remediate ongoing mold despite notice—constitute negligent and willful interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of her home.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case deals with landlord liability for drug-related crime and failure to provide security, not with failure to repair ventilation or remediate mold. It recognizes that a landlord’s omissions can constitute a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment when they permit conditions that seriously interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment, but it does not involve or discuss negligent or willful failure to remedy physical conditions like mold or ventilation defects. Thus, it provides general support for interference-with-quiet-enjoyment theories, but not specifically for mold/ventilation-based interference as framed in the proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold…. Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… [I]f the defendant has failed to take any measures… then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruickshank v. Boschma, 68 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Cruickshank v. Boschma, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 638 (2007)
Cruickshank v. Boschma, 68 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions—including failing to repair the ventilation and remediate ongoing mold despite notice—constitute negligent and willful interference with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of her home.
Cruickshank v. Boschma, 68 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about the validity of a guilty plea and standards for withdrawing that plea, not a civil case about interference with use and enjoyment of property, negligence, landlord-tenant duties, mold, or failure to repair. Nothing in the decision discusses willful or negligent interference with use and enjoyment of a home or analogous tort principles. The citation is therefore inapposite to the stated proposition.
Cruickshank v. Boschma, 68 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "In the context of a guilty plea, justice is not done when a defendant’s plea of guilt is not intelligent and voluntary... or is made without the advice of competent counsel.... A defendant who has received a constitutionally inadequate plea colloquy is entitled to withdraw that plea."

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was not an isolated act but an ongoing pattern of neglect that substantially impaired Plaintiff’s comfort, health, and enjoyment of her home.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts an ongoing pattern of neglect that substantially impaired the tenant’s comfort, health, and enjoyment. This opinion finds the opposite: the landlord promptly addressed the cited defects, the remaining issues were minor, and there was no breach of habitability or quiet enjoyment. The court explicitly states there was no evidence of interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, so the case undercuts rather than supports the claimed proposition.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: "Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. While these conditions were documented by the board of health pursuant to an inspection, a reinspection less than two weeks later indicated that substantially all the conditions had been satisfactorily addressed. ... The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises."

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: The breach of this covenant entitles Plaintiff to actual damages, and under G.L. c. 186, §14, recovery may include three months’ rent or three times the actual damages, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses G.L. c. 186, §14 only indirectly, as one of several counterclaims Gonzalez brought, but the SJC does not set out or apply the statutory remedial formula of “three months’ rent or three times the actual damages, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.” The damages analysis in the opinion focuses on G.L. c. 93A and the warranty of habitability, not on the specific measure of damages under §14. Therefore this case is not authority for the precise remedial rule stated in the proposition.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A (for the intentional infliction of emotional distress and violation of the warranty of habitability), and attorneys' fees and costs.… To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The breach of this covenant entitles Plaintiff to actual damages, and under G.L. c. 186, §14, recovery may include three months’ rent or three times the actual damages, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion in Berman & Sons v. Jefferson deals with common‑law rent abatement for breach of the implied warranty of habitability. It does not cite, interpret, or apply G.L. c. 186, §14, nor does it discuss statutory remedies such as three months’ rent or treble damages, attorney’s fees, or costs. The only remedy discussed is rent abatement measured by the difference between the value as warranted and in defective condition, so the case does not support the specific statutory damages proposition claimed.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The trial judge found that the measure of damages was “the difference between the value of the apartment as warranted and the rental value of the apartment in its defective condition.” See McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 306 (1977). Apart from the question whether the tenant’s rent abates only after the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair, damages are not in dispute in this case.
